Updated at 2.30pm GMT


 2.12pm GMT 

Sturgeon is being asked about her non-attendance at the â€œOperation Nimbusâ€ planning exercise in early 2020, which brought together senior figures from the UK government and other administrations.
With hindsight, her instinctive reaction might be that she should have been there, though she says that â€œnot everybody can be at everythingâ€ in times such as the ones they were living in.
The meeting was aimed at drawing up a â€˜battleplanâ€™, the inquiry has previously heard, and set out a scenario in which the virus had claimed 840,000 lives in the UK.

Updated at 2.30pm GMT


 2.00pm GMT 

Sturgeon is being asked about the resignation of Dr Catherine Calderwood, who quit her role as chief medical officer to the Scottish government in April 2020 after facing intense criticism for breaking her own rules to twice visit her second home during the coronavirus outbreak.
This happened at a pivotal moment when the government and its experts were settling into a rhythm, Sturgeon says. Calderwood was a pivotal part of that and the then First Minister was â€œmindfulâ€ of the disruption that could be caused from losing her.]
She eventually realised, as more reports emerged, that Calderwood would be unable to stay. Calderwood had already reached that decision and it was to her credit that she had been clear with the First Minister that public messaging had to take precedence, Sturgeon says.
This stands in contrast to â€œsome other episodes,â€ she says, in a potential reference, some might suspect, to the behaviour of those in government in London.

Updated at 2.02pm GMT


 1.55pm GMT 

The inquiry has returned and Sturgeon has said she had confidence in the advice she received from Scotlandâ€™s chief medical officers during the pandemic, despite none of the three coming from a respiratory disease or related background.
Sturgeon also moves again to speak up in defence of Dr Catherine Calderwood in response to a suggestion from counsel for the inquiry that Calderwood â€œdid not seem to have much of a planâ€ when it came to preparing to implement a strategy for testing.



 12.55pm GMT 

Sturgeon rejects the suggestion that there was any â€œculture of secrecyâ€ on the part of the Scottish government when it came to things like whether Scottish ministers covered up the first recorded Covid outbreak in Scotland, from a Nike conference in Edinburgh in February 2020.
In the case of Nike, the decision taken was informed by considerations of patient confidentiality, but she accepted that others may have taken a different view.
â€œOn Nike, I saw the potential â€“ I donâ€™t think this risk materialised â€“ I saw the potential for the Nike conference to emerge later through a media disclosure to undermine confidence. In hindsight I would have gone the other way,â€ she added.
The inquiry is now breaking and will return at 1.45pm.

Updated at 1.00pm GMT


 12.50pm GMT 

Sturgeon was asked about another aspect of planning â€“ the need for public messaging â€“ and she was asked if there had been a recommendation that keeping the public informed at an earlier stage was as important as the later process of daily briefings.
She says she recalls in advance of the briefings more regularly being asked about it in interviews, so the public messaging was something that her government was aware of.
Jamie Dawson KC (for the inquiry) says there was evidence of some things not being communicated to the public, such as the identity of the first person to die from Covid in Scotland and concerns about a rugby fixture. None of them were communicated at the time with any detail. Was this on the advice of Dr Catherine Calderwood, who was the chief medical officer in Scotland for a period before she later resigned?
Sturgeon says there were difference considerations in relation to those different examples.
She had discussed them with Dr Calderwood, though looking back now she might take a different decision. That said, she did not believe her advice was unreasonable.
A different physician might have had a different â€œrisk appetiteâ€ and given different advice, while a â€œdifferent politicianâ€ might have taken a different decision, she added.
She accepted the decisions made in that regard had the potential to undermine public messaging.

Updated at 1.01pm GMT


 12.41pm GMT 

Sturgeon is asked about previous evidence that the health system had lacked the kit and resources when it came to getting testing in place.
It didnâ€™t reflect a lack of urgency in terms of planning, she insists, and there was an intense supply chain pressure.
It took time for larger testing labs to be got up and running, although it would always have been the case that things didnâ€™t move as quickly as she would have liked.

Updated at 1.02pm GMT


 12.32pm GMT 
Sturgeon: 'At times I felt overwhelmed with what we were dealing with'

Sturgeon wipes away a tear, adding that in the early days of the pandemic her experience and view was that everyone was trying their best.
She insists that she did not see an opportunity of any sort in Covid, in answer to a question about whether she saw the pandemic as a political opportunity.
 





â€œYou have seen snippets of the human side of being a leader in those circumstances. At times I felt overwhelmed with what we were dealing with and perhaps more than anything I felt an overwhelming responsibility to do the best that I could.â€
â€œThe idea that in those horrendous days, weeks I was thinking of a political opportunity â€¦ I find â€¦ well, it just wasnâ€™t true,â€ she adds, appearing to be trying to hold off tears again.

Updated at 3.27pm GMT


 12.29pm GMT 
Sturgeon says Johnson was 'wrong prime minister' for Covid crisis

Sturgeon replies â€œyesâ€ when asked if Boris Johnson was â€œthe wrong prime ministerâ€ for the Covid-19 crisis.
Did she consider herself to be the right first minister for the job?
No, that is not how she would see things, says Sturgeon, as her voice cracks when she goes on to say that there is a large part of her which would have wished that she was not in that role.

Updated at 12.30pm GMT


 12.25pm GMT 

Sturgeon was asked about a WhatsApp exchange in which Jason Leitch, a clinical director who advised on the response to the pandemic by the Scottish government, referred to the then first ministerâ€™s â€œâ€˜keep it smallâ€™ shenanigansâ€.


Nicola Sturgeon was asked about comments on Whatsapp by an advisor to her govt that she favoured 'keep it small shenanigans" when it came ot meetings"You have to know Jason Leitch as well as I do to appreciate his sometimes turn of phrase," she responds pic.twitter.com/vSVqpcQciZâ€” Ben Quinn (@BenQuinn75) January 31, 2024


Leitch was â€œcrucial in a very positive way to our handling of the pandemicâ€, says Sturgeon.
She goes on to say that she suspects it was a reference to things that were sometimes said about her in government, which is that she â€œdidnâ€™t like a cast of unnecessary thousandsâ€ in meetings.

Updated at 12.44pm GMT


 12.18pm GMT 

From the start of her evidence this morning, Nicola Sturgeon has appeared on edge, defensive, occasionally adopting that head girl-ish â€œI know bestâ€ tone that will be familiar to those who watched her briefings during the pandemic.
But there was a flare of genuine emotion at the end of the first morning session, when Dawson asked her about a story which appeared in the Express this morning which suggested that she and the former health secretary Jeane Freeman had purchased â€œburner phonesâ€ at the start of the pandemic.
Whilst there are questions to ask about use of phones by ministers â€“ earlier Sturgeon admitted she had only used a personal phone during her time as first minister â€“ the insinuation of this particular report were dubious at best, and it was a surprise that Dawson raised it.
Sturgeon immediately explained that the purchases were made by her constituency staff as office landlines were diverted to mobiles once lockdown was imposed â€“ many other MSPs would have done likewise she said.
But the trembling and twitching of her lips and the wetting of her eyes suggested she was struggling to keep her emotions in check. Was she frustrated that Dawson was raising such a trivial bit of mischief-making amidst otherwise serious questioning? Or simply responding to highly pressurised questioning?

Updated at 12.22pm GMT


 12.16pm GMT 

The inquiry is being shown notes taken by Liz Lloyd, Sturgeonâ€™s former chief of staff, from a meeting in 2020 about steps taken to mitigate the financial impact of a so-called â€˜circuit breakerâ€™ lockdown.
In a previous hearing, Lloyd had been asked about her suggestion of â€œpolitical tactics calling for things we canâ€™t do to force the UKâ€.
Sturgeon says this was a period of 2020 which culminated in the second lockdown in England and enhanced measure in Scotland. It was the point when there was a â€œdisjointâ€ between the ability of the Scottish government to take public health decisions and inability to borrow money to compensate businesses was coming to the fore.
â€œThis was a frustration that was expressed regularly by us,â€ she says, adding that the same frustration was felt by officials in Northern Ireland and Wales.
â€œThis was, to be blunt, the Scottish government seeking to ensure, if we had to apply tougher restrictions, Scottish workers would get their wages paid and Scottish businesses would be able to cover their costs in the same way as those in England would.â€
Sturgeon says she rejects any suggestion that Kate Forbes, as finance secretary, was excluded from those meetings
She did not operate in on any issue in a way that sought to exclude people from decision making, she insists.
â€œI tried to lead from the front. I tried to shoulder my fair share sometimes more than my fair share of the decision making given the severity,â€
But she goes on to say: â€œI am sitting here thinking I donâ€™t know why she wasnâ€™t there that day, maybe she should have been in it and it was not a deliberate attempt to exclude her in any way.â€

Updated at 12.32pm GMT


 12.03pm GMT 

Sturgeon has been asked by comments from Kate Forbes who said she â€œwasnâ€™t invitedâ€ to any of the high-level Scottish government pandemic response meetings in 2020 despite being finance secretary at the time. Forbes also told the inquiry she was not even aware of the so-called â€œgold commandâ€ meetings which Sturgeon had convened.
Sturgeon says there would have been nothing to stop her from attending those meetings if she had wanted to and her office was copied in to the notice of the meetings and papers.

Updated at 12.15pm GMT


 12.00pm GMT 
Sturgeon 'strongly refutes' allegation she did not like light to be shone on how Scottish government made decisions

Jamie Dawson KC, for the inquiry, puts it to her that there has been a theme developing that the Scottish government which she led â€œdid not like light to be shoneâ€ on the manner in which decisions were taken during the pandemic.
â€œI would very strongly refute that,â€ Sturgeon replies, going on to tell Dawson that she had looked at all the cabinet papers from the whole period, which ran to thousands of pages.
That paperwork does not just simply recall the decisions that were reached, and the options, but also gives a â€œcomprehensive recordâ€, which included the â€œthought processes and rationalesâ€.

Updated at 12.16pm GMT


 11.56am GMT 

Sturgeon is now being asked about something the UK Covid inquiry is struggling to understand in relation to how she took key decisions during the pandemic because her â€œgold commandâ€ meetings were not minuted.
Jamie Dawson KC, the inquiryâ€™s Scottish counsel, has said previously it appeared that the Scottish government failed to record discussions during any of Sturgeonâ€™s crucial â€œgoldâ€ meetings with a small handful of her advisers and senior ministers during 2020 and 2021.
Asked about it today, Sturgeon essentially denies gold meeting were examples of her dictating policy without being minuted. Ultimately, cabinet made the decisions and set the policy, she insists.
Thereâ€™s more here on the issue, as reported by my colleague Severin Carrell yesterday.

 Related: No minutes kept of Nicola Sturgeonâ€™s â€˜gold commandâ€™ meetings, Covid inquiry told 


Updated at 12.17pm GMT


 11.43am GMT 

Sturgeon is shown a WhatsApp exchange in which Humza Yousaf, then health minister, was discussing the possibility of further lockdown related measures, but where there were questions about funding for business.
The inquiry has heard that Yousaf told cabinet that he had found money from his budget. In the WhatsApp messages, Yousaf said that â€œhe had taken a bulletâ€ at the meeting and that the then first minister â€œwas not remotely happy its at this last stage.â€
Dawson puts it to her that there was a culture where Sturgeon didnâ€™t want to countenance things which she had not had advance sight of
â€œThere was no such culture in the government I led,â€ she says. Cabinet discussions were robust and earnest and she expected ministers to be able to come and argue for the decisions they wanted to take.

Updated at 11.46am GMT


 11.35am GMT 

The inquiry is back now again and has moved on to the decision-making process.
Before then, however, itâ€™s worth reporting on this exchange we didnâ€™t get to earlier in which Sturgeon said she â€œperhaps shouldnâ€™t haveâ€ given an SNP address to Prof Devi Sridhar, who advised the Scottish government during the coronavirus outbreak
The inquiry saw messages between the pair where the then first minister gave Sridhar an SNP email address as well as a Scottish government email address.
She said: â€œOn reflection perhaps I shouldnâ€™t have done that.
â€œBut if I had been in any way trying to direct her to a private email address, I doubt if I would have put my government email address in there as well.â€

Updated at 11.47am GMT


 11.20am GMT 

Sturgeon is being asked about her use of a personal phone â€“ as other members of her government did â€“ and whether she felt it was appropriate.
It was never suggested to me at any time during my period as first minister that it was not appropriate, she replies. She used a personal phone because she didnâ€™t want to have multiple devices.
Jamie Dawson KC, for the inquiry, asks her about a report yesterday in the Scottish Daily Express that Sturgeon and Jeane Freeman, the Scottish governmentâ€™s health secretary at the time, purchased cheap mobile phones and prepaid top-up cards during the early months of the Covid pandemic.
Sturgeon says that they were the phones her constituency office landline were diverted to in the homes of her constituency workers.
She had never â€œto the best of my knowledge seen heard or used any of the phones.â€
The inquiry is now taking a break until 11.30 before it moves on to other areas of questioning by Dawson.

Updated at 11.49am GMT


 11.11am GMT 

Sturgeon has been shown exchanges from another WhatsApp group â€“ which she was not a part of â€“ in which a civil servant appeared to be encouraging others to delete records that could be recoverable under the freedom of information act
She says she â€œcanâ€™t answerâ€ for Ken Thomson, the civil servant who made the remark, but she insists that her experience of him was that he was â€œassiduousâ€ and took his duties and responsibilities seriously
â€œI can only speak about my experience of him and I can give an answer based on my interpretation of it, which was that it was meant to be a light-hearted discussion,â€ she added.


Sturgeon wasn't in this Whatsapp group but she's being asked about a Scottish government civil servant who appeared to have been encouraging others to delete messages that could be recovered under FOICan't answer for him but she suggests it was "light hearted" pic.twitter.com/iAONXTNZLiâ€” Ben Quinn (@BenQuinn75) January 31, 2024



Updated at 11.49am GMT


 11.03am GMT 

Sturgeon is being pressed at length on the rationale for not storing WhatsApp messages. The position she keeps on returning to is that any decisions taken would have been discussed at cabinet level and recorded there.


At the Covid inquiry, Nicola Sturgeon is being asked about her deletion of whatsappsWould an exchange like this not have been one that would have informed a public understanding later?There was nothing in this exchange that would not have been recored in public record she says pic.twitter.com/ULOVEA0SBsâ€” Ben Quinn (@BenQuinn75) January 31, 2024


In many cases, she insists, she would have been standing at a podium later in the day being questioned about the issues at hand.

Updated at 11.06am GMT


 10.50am GMT 
Sturgeon admits deleting WhatsApp messages

Sturgeon once again says she wants to be â€œvery clearâ€ that it was not her practice to have lengthy or detailed discussions through â€œthese meansâ€ â€“ a reference to WhatsApp.
â€œItâ€™s not my style,â€ she insists.
What follows is an exchange between Sturgeon and Dawson over the manner in which messages were not retained on her phone. Dawson asks if she is making a distinction between deletion and not retaining messages, to which she tells him she was â€œvery thoroughâ€ to keep to the advice she had been given about the retention of records.
â€œBut did you delete them?â€ asks Dawson
â€œYes,â€ comes the answer.
 






Updated at 1.39pm GMT


 10.43am GMT 

There was a frenetic pace in government at the time and the situation was changing several times a day, says Sturgeon. Three, four years on, itâ€™s hard to appreciate that, she insists.
Dawson says however the fact that you are working at pace does not alter the need to ensure that decisions taken are stored on the corporate record.
As the conversation moves on, Sturgeon says that decisions taken were ones by their very nature were ones that could not be kept secret because they were ones the public was being asked to take.
I didnâ€™t get to it earlier, but itâ€™s worth reporting that Sturgeon says she was being asked during the pandemic to take decisions which she and other politicians had never experienced before. Her voice seemed to break a little bit as she added that she â€œthinks about them every day.â€



 10.34am GMT 

Dawson is pressing Sturgeon a bit further on how seriously she took the retention of records.
â€œI knew I had operated in line with a policy I had operated in line with to ensure that conversations with others in government should not be kept in a phone that could be lost or destroyed,â€ she replies.
Surgeon is also asked about an exchange she had with a Channel 4 journalist who had asked her if she would ensure that all emails and WhatsApps would be retained. You can view it here


â€˜Can you guarantee to the bereaved families that you will disclose emails, WhatsApps, private emails if youâ€™ve been using them. Whatever. That nothing will be off limits in this inquiry?â€™My question to @NicolaSturgeon August 2021 pic.twitter.com/OJDCBTESCeâ€” Ciaran Jenkins (@C4Ciaran) October 29, 2023


â€œI also knew that anything of any relevance or substance would be properly recorded in the Scottish government system,â€ she replies.
She says that she wants to underline that in her case â€œthat communicationâ€ [WhatsApp] was extremely limited and would not apply to matters of substantive decision making.
But that wasnâ€™t the question that Channel 4 had asked her, Dawson says.
Sturgeon apologises if her answer to the journalist was not â€œas clearâ€ and wants to give the inquiry a â€œpersonal assuranceâ€ that the inquiry has â€œeverything and everythingâ€ germane to her decision making during the crisis.

Updated at 11.07am GMT


 10.26am GMT 

Sturgeon says she canâ€™t recall receiving an email which a Scottish government civil servant had sent out with a â€œdo not destroy notification for members of the administration to remind them to retain records.
â€œI do not. As far as I am aware I did not receive that,â€ Sturgeon tells Dawson, who goes on to suggest she would recall if such a communication was sent out.
â€œI donâ€™t think I would have required to see that to know that matters that were relevant, matters of substance, salient matters that would be relevant to the inquiry â€¦ should be retained.â€

Updated at 10.47am GMT


 10.21am GMT 
Use of WhatsApp 'too common' in Scottish government, Sturgeon says, but was not used for Covid decisions

WhatsApp had become â€“ maybe â€“ too common a means of communication in government, says Sturgeon.
But she insists that government decisions were not being taken on the platform.
One of the reasons why she doesnâ€™t believe it should be used for government decision making is that when politicians make public statements they should think very carefully about the scope for what they say being misinterpreted.
â€œWhen you send things on WhatsApp you sometimes donâ€™t think â€“ including me â€“ very carefully about how they can be interpreted,â€ she adds.

Updated at 10.33am GMT


 10.18am GMT 

Speaking about previous messages which the inquiry has seen, Sturgeon says she is not sure if she has seen any messages which contained material that the Scottish public would not otherwise have seen.
â€œIt might be for the Scottish public to judge,â€ interjects Jamie Dawson KC, for the inquiry.
â€œOf course,â€ replies Sturgeon, who insists that it was an â€œopen conversationâ€ with the public throughout the pandemic.

Updated at 10.52am GMT


 10.14am GMT 

The WhatsApp issue has come up with haste and Sturgeon says that she was never a member of any Whatsapp groups and interacted through â€œinformal messaging systemsâ€ with no more than a dozen people.
Principally, she would have communicated with her former chief of staff Liz Lloyd and Humza Yousaf, her successor as Scotlandâ€™s First Minister and SNP leader but who was a member of her government at the time.
Communication of that nature was not used by me for anything other than routine exchanges and would have been â€œlitteredâ€ with things like â€œthereâ€™s a note coming from me to you.â€
Sturgeon says she operated on the basis that she would ensure that anything in communications of an important nature was otherwise recorded on the Scottish government system.

Updated at 10.35am GMT


 10.08am GMT 

Is it still your position today that you and the Scottish government were open â€œopen, transparent and accountableâ€ not just in your actions but in your words?, asks Jamie Dawson KC
â€œYes, that is still my position. Openess and transparency with the Scottish public was very important to me from the outset,â€ says Sturgeon.
There will have been misjudgements and there will have been â€“ on reflection â€“ instances on which we could have done better, she adds.



 10.05am GMT 

â€œYou are Nicola Sturgeon,â€ the former SNP leader is asked after she takes her seat.
â€œI am..â€
And with that the questioning is underway. Sturgeon confirms she has provided some additional material to the inquiry last week, in addition to her earlier statements.
Question immediately focuses on communications during the pandemic.



 9.58am GMT 
Nicola Sturgeon gives evidence at UK Covid inquiry

Nicola Sturgeon, the former Scottish First Minister, is appearing before the Covid Inquiry in Edinburgh in what is the biggest day of the probeâ€™s focus on that part of the UK.
For long the pre-eminent figure in Scottish politics, Sturgeon has experienced a dramatic fall from grace in the time since she was at the helm of her governmentâ€™s response to the pandemic.
But while she was lauded by many at the time, she faces a range of awkward questions during an examination that is likely to see her draw on all of her experience as a lawyer and political representative.
Those questions are likely to cover the following areas, and more:
â€¢ The inquiry has previously heard that the former SNP leaded did not retain any of her WhatsApp messages. Why?
â€¢ Sturgeon had pledged to hand over all of her communications from the pandemic. In what circumstances did they disappear or were deleted?
â€¢ Guidance on the use of WhatsApp was issued by the Scottish government in 2021. Did she follow those rules and, if not, why not?
â€¢ Sturgon has been accused of seeking to use the pandemic as a way of leveraging support for Scottish independence. Did she seek to deliberately engage in a politically self-serving row with the UK government over issues such as the Furlough Scheme?
This covering her answers to those questions â€“ and anything else â€“ on this liveblog, along with in-person reporting at the Inquiry from my colleagues Severin Carrell and Libby Brooks.

title: UK businesses: how will you be affected by the new Brexit food checks?
content: New food checks for products such as cheeses and meats imported into the UK from the EU mark a big change since the country left the single market in January 2021. The changes, known as the Border Target Operating Model, will require all imports of medium and high risk products, which include meat and dairy and the majority of plants, to be sent with export health certificates from Wednesday. On 30 April, these products will receive physical checks at the border before they can enter the UK. We would like to know what impact â€“ if any â€“ the changes will have on your business? How might it affect the products you offer? What effect might it have on your suppliers? We are also interested in hearing from consumers and if they have experienced any changes.  Callout

title: New Brexit food checks likely to mean less choice, warn delis
content: Thousands of delicatessens and other specialist food shops have said new border rules that come in from Wednesday are likely to mean reduced choice of products for consumers. The Guild of Fine Food (GFF), which represents 12,000 businesses, has raised fears that European suppliers of specialist foods such as cheeses and meats will stop supplying the UK as a result of the additional red tape for imported goods. John Farrand, the managing director at the GFF, said: â€œIâ€™m just worried that we are going to end up buying and selling only mass produced products. Are we going to see the end of smaller, more interesting products, which are ultimately better for the planet?â€ The government is introducing the biggest changes to the way the UK imports food and plant products from the EU since it left the single market in January 2021. The changes, known as the Border Target Operating Model, will require all imports of medium and high risk products, which include meat and dairy and the majority of plants, to be sent with export health certificates from Wednesday. On 30 April, these products will receive physical checks at the border before they can enter the UK. The new requirements have caused widespread concern that they could result in some smaller suppliers giving up on supplying the UK because of the extra costs. Farrand said while large supermarkets and large exporting businesses would have the financial base and resources to continue ensuring supply, smaller retailers and wholesalers would not. Andrea Rasca, the CEO and founder of Mercato Metropolitano, which runs a number of sites in London hosting dozens of independent food outlets, agreed that the new rules would deter EU suppliers, and urged the government to rethink. Rasca said: â€œFor independent retailers, these new import rules could result in many specialty retailers or delis having empty shelves and at worst having to close down due to the limited supply of produce coming into the UK.â€ According to the government, the additional costs of the border checks and new certification requirements could add up to another Â£330m a year of extra costs for business. Nick Carlucci, the sales director at the Italian food importer Tenuta Marmorelle, said that he had heard of several suppliers in Italy opting against exporting to the UK because of the post-Brexit red tape. He said: â€œThey have said it is not worth our while â€“ the UK is not a big enough market for us. Itâ€™s a shame because the end user will ultimately lose these specialist products.â€ In a statement, the government said the new controls would help prevent the import of diseases and pests from overseas. The biosecurity minister, Lord Douglas-Miller, said they were â€œproportionate and pragmaticâ€ and the government had worked closely with industry before finalising plans. He added: â€œThe controls introduced today strike the right balance between trade and biosecurity.â€ MPs, however, have raised concerns about whether biosecurity will be sufficiently protected. In a letter to the environment minister, Steve Barclay, the environment, food and rural affairs committee said that it was particularly concerned with the plan to carry out border checks at the Sevington border post, which is 22 miles inland from the Port of Dover. The letter said that the plan presented a â€œpotentially serious biosecurity riskâ€ and also compromised compliance regarding lorries carrying goods. It added: â€œWe understand that drivers will be under no obligation to go to Sevington, if asked to do so. As such, we have real and reasonable concerns about the geographic dislocation of the inland border facility from the point of entry.â€ A government spokesperson said: â€œThis is not something we expect to see, having developed the model and its timelines for implementation through extensive consultation with industry stakeholders. â€œOur plan will help deliver the most advanced border in the world, progressively introducing an innovative approach to importing. â€œThis includes using technology and data to make it simple for businesses to trade, while maintaining the flow and security of goods helping to keep the UK safe, while protecting our food supply-chains and our agricultural sector from disease outbreaks that would cause significant economic harm. â€œWe have and will continue to work with industry, ports and airports to prepare for the changes being implemented.â€

title: Rish! puts himself through his hardest ordeal yet â€“ ITVâ€™s This Morning sofa | John Crace
content: When the going gets tough â€¦ Rishi Sunak has never been the type of politician to duck a challenge. One of the phrases he repeats most often is that he chooses to do things â€œnot because they are easy but because they are hardâ€. So on Tuesday morning the prime minister put himself through his hardest ordeal yet: ITVâ€™s This Morning sofa. First, though, he was invited to try some fried chicken and tomato pasta that had been knocked up by the TV chef. Rish! grinned awkwardly and tried to look like a man at home with spontaneity. Rather, he just seemed like the random work experience teenager who had mistakenly walked on set. Or the producerâ€™s son who had bunked off school for the day with a sore throat. The presenters Rylan Clark and Rochelle Humes quickly took control, escorting Sunak over to the sofa in the ad break and giving him a cushion to sit on. â€œRight,â€ said Rylan, flashing his brilliant white teeth. â€œThank you for coming on. Letâ€™s get on with the interview because Iâ€™ve got some enormously tough questions for you. First off, Northern Ireland. Have the DUP backed down or is the UK going to stay aligned with EU law? And is the Â£3bn basically just a bribe?â€ Rish! looked dazzled. Panic-struck, even. Rylan broke out into a laugh and patted the prime minister affectionately on the knee. â€œJust kidding!â€ What he really wanted to know was how Sunakâ€™s fast had gone. Not too bad, the prime minister said, though he wasnâ€™t as disciplined as he would like to be. So he did have the odd nut? â€œOh, yes,â€ laughed Rish!. The cabinet was full of them. Boom, boom. Then we moved on to vaping. It was very important to stop kids vaping. But he didnâ€™t want to put adults off trying to stop smoking. There was a balance to be struck. Rylan and Rochelle nodded attentively. This was cutting-edge TV.    Related: Pharmacist at former Sunak family chemist wary of PMâ€™s health plans   It could be hard to get an appointment to see a GP, Rylan observed. â€œThatâ€™s why weâ€™ve made it easier to see a pharmacist,â€ said Sunak. Rather missing the point. â€œMy mother was a pharmacist.â€ Really? Who knew? â€œFrom tomorrow you can see a pharmacist for seven common conditions.â€ Like the sort of things people already go to see a pharmacist for because they know they wonâ€™t be able to see a doctor. Rochelle chipped in. Most people didnâ€™t want to go to see a pharmacist if they had cancer or needed a knee replacement. A waste of everyoneâ€™s time. â€œMy dad was a GP,â€ said Sunak. As if that somehow made him a medical expert. Then he backtracked. He wasnâ€™t saying people had to see a pharmacist. Just that they could if they wanted to. There was always their GP if they could get an appointment. We were back where we started. â€œWe want to improve telephony,â€ Rish! insisted. The problem wasnâ€™t that there werenâ€™t enough GPs. It was that most surgeries didnâ€™t have the right phone lines. What was needed was more systems that allowed artificial intelligence to inform patients they were unable to see a doctor that day. Press 1 to be told there is a two-month delay for an ultrasound, press 2 to be told that a locum will ring you sometime in the next week. And press 3 if you are happy to die while waiting. Rylan wondered why the government didnâ€™t just offer doctors more cash. Wouldnâ€™t that be the best way of bringing down waiting lists? Absolutely not, said Sunak. Heâ€™d already been quite generous enough. Most doctors were already far too rich. Didnâ€™t know they were born. Now was the time to think of the really destitute. The government ministers who were on the breadline earning Â£118,000. Would no one take pity on them? Just then, ITV ran a banner across the screen. â€œCall 0845 600 600 and get through to George Freemanâ€™s JustGiving page. A donation of just Â£200 could buy George dinner for two at his favourite Mayfair restaurant. Remember, an MP isnâ€™t just for Christmasâ€. Rylan and Rochelle collapsed into tears. Broken people. title: Sinn FÃ©in says united Ireland â€˜within touching distanceâ€™ as Stormont deal agreed
content:
Sinn FÃ©in has said a united Ireland is â€œwithin touching distanceâ€ as the party prepares to claim the post of Northern Ireland first minister for the first time.
Mary Lou McDonald said on Tuesday that the expected restoration of power sharing in the wake of a deal between the Democratic Unionist party and the UK government came amid a â€œhistorical turning of the wheelâ€ that would unite the island.
â€œIn historic terms, it is within touching distance and I think that is a very exciting thing and I hope people will find that a very welcoming conversation,â€ the Sinn FÃ©in leader said.
According to a speedy political choreography that is supposed to unfold at Westminster on Wednesday and Thursday, her deputy, Michelle Oâ€™Neill, could become first minister of the Stormont executive by the weekend.
â€œThat will be a moment of very great significance, not simply because we havenâ€™t had government for so long but because it will be the first time that we will have a Sinn FÃ©in first minister, a nationalist first minister,â€ McDonald said.
Oâ€™Neill became the regionâ€™s putative first minister when Sinn FÃ©in overtook the DUP as the biggest party in the 2022 assembly election. But a DUP boycott to protest against post-Brexit trading arrangements mothballed Stormont.
The DUP leader, Sir Jeffrey Donaldson, signalled an end to two years of deadlock early on Tuesday when a tumultuous meeting of the partyâ€™s 130-member executive endorsed a deal to revive power sharing.
The deal will remove restrictions on the movement of goods within the UK, Donaldson said. â€œThat was our core key objective and I believe what we have secured represents real change and everybody will be able to see it for themselves.â€
He has promised â€œzero checks, zero customs paperwork on goods moving within the United Kingdomâ€. The DUP endorsement is conditional on two statutory instruments at Westminster to give legislative effect to Downing Street commitments on trade and sovereignty.
Chris Heaton-Harris, the UKâ€™s Northern Ireland secretary, said the deal featured a â€œvast array of decent improvementsâ€ and would be published on Wednesday. The legislation is expected to be fast-tracked through Westminster on Thursday. A spokesperson for Rishi Sunak said the deal was a â€œstrong basisâ€ to restore Stormont.
Downing Street said the prime minister had a â€œgood callâ€ with Leo Varadkar. Irelandâ€™s taoiseach has welcomed the deal but he cautioned that Dublin and Brussels needed to see the text to be confident there were no â€œnegative consequencesâ€ for the Windsor framework or for the Good Friday agreement. The European Commission echoed the guarded welcome. â€œWe will examine those texts when the time comes,â€ said a spokesperson.
Conservative MPs have expressed concern the deal could limit Great Britainâ€™s ability to diverge from EU rules in the future to limit the impact of an Irish Sea border on internal trade with Northern Ireland. Downing Street said the deal would not prevent the UK from exploiting post-Brexit freedoms.
If there are no glitches, Stormont could be recalled as early as Friday to elect an assembly speaker and appoint an executive drawn from Sinn FÃ©in, the DUP, the Alliance party and the Ulster Unionist party. The DUP will be entitled to the deputy first minister post, which has equal power to first minister but less prestige and symbolic weight.
 





Oâ€™Neill said Stormont faced an urgent workload, including a fiscal crisis, strikes and crumbling healthcare. â€œWe have a lot of hard work ahead of us, a slog ahead of us, but collectively we can do better for the people we serve. Collectively, we can fight back against this Tory austerity agenda, collectively we can stand up and fight hard for public services.â€
The government has offered a Â£3.3bn financial package that is conditional on Stormontâ€™s restoration. It includes funding for pay rises that could avert public sector strikes, though not a strike by transport workers that is to go ahead on Thursday.
The Alliance leader, Naomi Long, said the breakthrough deal brought â€œbittersweet emotionsâ€ because of the time Stormont had been absent.
Matthew Oâ€™Toole, of the Social Democratic and Labour party, said it was â€œnot the time for champagne corks to pop or balloons to be released in celebrationâ€ given the failures of the past two years.
Jim Allister, the leader of the hardline Traditional Unionist Voice, accused the DUP of a â€œtawdry climbdownâ€ and said its boycott should continue.

title: Goods to flow freely from GB to NI as part of deal to restore Stormont power sharing, says DUP â€“ as it happened

5.46pm GMT 
Afternoon summary


Michelle Oâ€™Neill, the Sinn FÃ©in leader in Northern Ireland, is poised to become the first nationalist first minister at Stormont after the DUP said it would be lifting its boycott of power sharing. The DUP agreed to resume participation in the power sharing executive, which has been suspended for almost two years, on the basis of a deal agreed with the UK government to revise some of the post-Brexit trading rules that disadvantaged Northern Ireland. Sir Jeffrey Donaldson, the DUP leader, played down the significance of Oâ€™Neill becoming first minister (see 3.51pm), but it is bound to be seen as a historic moment for Northern Ireland, where the unionists have been the dominant political community for most of the last century and where Sinn FÃ©in was for many years marginalised because of its links with the IRA. Donaldson also claimed the deal was a victory for his party, because it confounded critics who claimed the DUP would never be able to change the legal terms of the Windsor framework. (See 4.49pm.) Details of the deal have not yet been published, and it is possible that their release tomorrow will lead to claims that Donaldson has over-sold what has been achieved. But with Sinn FÃ©in and other parties welcoming the prospect of Stormont being revised, Dublin and Brussels apparently relaxed about the Windsor framework being altered, and no significant figures from the DUP speaking out against the deal, the Northern Ireland executive does seem on course to return within days.


The International Monetary Fund has issued a strong warning to Jeremy Hunt against cutting taxes in his budget in March, stressing the need to boost key areas of public spending instead.


The UK Covid inquiry is struggling to understand how Nicola Sturgeon took key decisions during the pandemic because her â€œgold commandâ€ meetings were not minuted, the inquiry has heard.


Keir Starmerâ€™s office has begun polling British Muslim voters amid growing concern in senior Labour ranks about the damage done to their core vote by the row over the partyâ€™s position on the Middle East.

Donaldson says DUP has confounded critics who said it would never be able to achieve 'legal change' to Windsor framework

Here are some more quotes from what Sir Jeffrey Donaldson said in his news conference at Stormont this afternoon.

Donaldson, the DUP leader, said he had confounded critics who claimed his party would never be able to achieve legal changes to the Windsor framework. He said:


Those who said there will be no legal change, who were predicting things would fall short, I simply asked people to wait and see the outcome. Wait and see the evidence and judge for yourself what this deal does, what it delivers, the change that it secures. I believe we are now beginning to see on day one that delivery coming through.


He said the DUP had negotiated the removal of extra checks on goods coming from Britain to Northern Ireland and due to stay there. He said:


On checks, on goods, moving between Great Britain and Northern Ireland and staying within the UK, there will no longer be physical checks, identity checks, save where, as is normal in any part of the UK, there is a suspicion of smuggling, of criminal activity; that is the same for every part of the United Kingdom.


He said â€œsupplementaryâ€ customs declarations would no longer be needed. He said:


On customs paperwork, customs declarations, supplementary declarations, will be gone and therefore we believe this represents a significant change.


And he said the â€œgreen laneâ€, a Windsor framework arrangement for goods going from Britain to Northern Ireland and not destined for Ireland, would go. He said:


As far as we are concerned, the green lane will go and be replaced by the UK internal market system that reflects the reality that Northern Ireland is part of the United Kingdom, that goods flowing within the United Kingdom, flow freely.
That was our core key objective and I believe what we have secured represents real change and everybody will be able to see it for themselves.

James Crisp from the Telegraph reported on this last week â€“ although he suggested the the rebranding was partly cosmetic.

What is in the deal?
Donaldson said it would end â€œdynamic alignmentâ€ whereby future changes in EU law would have to be observed in Northern Ireland.
Pending the dealâ€™s publication on Wednesday, it appears that Sunak has offered to keep Great Britain (England, Wales and Scotland) aligned with European standards if the DUP returned to Stormont.

The House of Lords voted to give the second reading of the Rwanda bill at 9.30am.
The Lib Dems forced a vote on an amendment to block the bill, but it was easily defeated. The Lords never normally votes on bills at second reading, and it only votes down bills at this point very rarely (just three times this century). Labour is opposed to the bill, but it did not vote with the Lib Dems because it accepts the convention that the Lords is there to revise bills passed by the Commons, not to reject them, as its spokesperson explained in the debate yesterday.
Here is the division list naming the handful of Labour and crossbench peers who voted with the Lib Dems for the blocking amendment.
The bill will now go to a committee of the whole house, which means that all peers can participate in the line-by-line debate on the bill. They will debate amendments, and some will almost certainly be passed. There will then be a vote at third reading. At that point peers could again, in theory, throw out the whole bill. But they wonâ€™tâ€™; theyâ€™ll send it back to the Commons amended.
There will be debates in February but the report stage, when most votes take place, is not due to start until March. The third reading debate is provisionally scheduled for 12 March.
The government cannot sent refugees to Rwanda until the bill becomes law because the supreme court has ruled that unlawful.
